title: Amazon Prime scam costs victims £400,000 in two months
text:
Scammers are tricking Amazon Prime customers (Picture: Getty)

Unsuspecting Amazon Prime customers are being tricked into handing over their details.

A new scam has seen victims lose more than £400,000 in two months, according to Action Fraud.

It said it had received 500 reports from people who had been targeted by conmen over the phone.

Customers are initially sent an automated call that tells them someone has signed up to Amazon Prime using their details.

They are told to press 1 to cancel the service and are then redirected to a real fraudster who pretends to be part of Amazon customer services.

The scam has cost victims £400,000 in two months(Picture: Getty)

The scammer tells them a subscription was bought in their name and they need to download the Team Viewer app and fill in their bank details so they can stop a similar attack in the future.

What the customer doesn’t know is the app allows the fraudster to access their computer and see their details, including bank information.

Victims are also sometimes told their info is needed so they can be given a refund following a fraudulent purchase on their account.

An Amazon spokesperson said: ‘We take phishing and spoofing attempts on our customers seriously, and will never call a customer for payment outside of our website.

‘If a customer has concerns or receives a call they believe is not from Amazon, they can check the Amazon.co.uk help pages for guidance using this link.’

Experts advise customers to never provide personal or financial information to unsolicited callers.

People can report fraudulent activity to Citizens Advice or Action Fraud.
description: Unsuspecting Amazon Prime customers are being tricked into handing over their personal details.
